field_edited_text.value:
SECGTION B: 29TH STREET TO 41ST STREET

9. The Mill Cafe: Part of the old Mount Vernon Mills can be
remodeled as a restaurant. It now overlooks a delightful ter-
race and another lovely falls. A water wheel could be recon-
structed. Two charming small buildings, dated 1873-79, can
be used as a textile museum.

10. Residential Potential — Falls Cliff: The magnificent view of
the Falls, the Valley, Druid Hill Park, and a skyline backdrop
of the very heart of Downtown from this high bluff gives the
Falls Cliff area an intensive residential potential. The “Mill
Town” across the ravine to the southeast is a handsome ex-
ample of company-built houses, the value of which will in-
crease as the Plan is carried out.

11. Hamden Hill: This promontory has a direct view down the

Valley to the heart of the City. On it is the historic Carroll
House. The top of the hill should be added to Roosevelt Park.

12. The Scenic Road: From Maryland Avenue to the point at

which the present Falls Road leaves the Valley at Hamden,

the road is to be widened under a current City program. The
new portion of the scenic route begins, then, where the pre-
sent Clipper Mill Road continues north from Falls Road.
From this point all the way to Prettyboy Reservoir, the road
will be a small-scaled, steep and winding one, a true scenic
route such as San Martin Drive in Wyman Park or Falls Road
in the county. With removal of the old and obsolete mill build-
ing in this area, the Jones Falls Valley Road underpasses the
expressway and rises on the other side to meet the hill in
Druid Hill Park.

13. Residential Rehabilitation and New Construction: Here
another promontory overlooks the Valley. With the Valley
Park below, a rapid transit station adjacent, Druid Hill Park
across the way, and Roosevelt Park nearby, this area will be
ripe for more intensive development, consistent with the Park
environment and transit and highway access.

14. Park Addition: This area is a logical part of Druid Hill Park
and the Valley concept. It is important visually as well as
locationally that this slope and the small stream at its bottom
be under Park protection. To the east, Brick Hill is another
natural portion of the Park. The houses are old, in many cases
in poor repair, and can be acquired gradually as they come
on the market. A new road connecting the Druid Hill Park
network and the Scenic Road is shown on Brick Hill. From
this height the road can overpass Union Avenue and continue
north along Clipper Avenue. Here a second group of stone
company houses stand close on the west side of the Road. The
City can acquire these over a period of time, lease them back
to present owners, or utilize them for Park purposes. An



O

|
l|
A
\‘ 0 U

" Woodberry Meadow . . . a focus for residences on the surrounding ridges.

agreement with the Woodberry Methodist Church should be
made so that its property could not change its present use or
pass to ownership other than that of the City.

15. Mill Recreation Area: The flood plain upon which the old
Mount Vernon Woodberry Mill #2 stands is ideal for active
recreational purposes such as lacrosse and football. The Olm-
sted Brothers pointed this out in 1902; it still holds true in
1961. The mill buildings have changed hands several times
in the past few years; the City should take advantage of the
next opportunity to acquire the property. The tower with its
handsome cupola could be preserved as a landmark.

16. Woodberry Meadow: Here the Valley concept sinks or
swims. The expressway is hemmed in closely as it narrowly
misses the unsightly factories; the Scenic Road borders the
western edge. This low-lying meadowland will give forth
quickly with moisture-loving plant life. It would be supple-
mented by landscape development so that the meadow will
become a focus for residential neighborhoods on the surround-
ing ridges.

An unimproved 8.8-acre tract in the Jones Falls flood plain at
the 41st Street viaduct should be acquired immediately. The
substantial industry now in this part of the Valley—including
the rag plant, the foundry, the envelope and rubber plants—
shoutd be acquired and razed as the buildings go out of use,
are partly or wholly lost due to natural circumstances or
calamities, or become obsolete. Their eventual elimination is
necessary to the Valley concept.

17. Residential Potential: This area is now partially improved
by small and light industrial concerns, but is still predomi-
nantly open land. The eastern slopes of the Valley rise to give
good views both north and south. The area has good access
to 41st Street, Falls Road, 36th Street, and an existing play-
ground. The industrial traffic and use at this location is in-
compatible with and damaging to the good housing near it.
